1.subquestion: Is there any possibility that Marcus might not need to submit the work based solely on having no regular or substitue teacher present?

subanswer.text: Let's analyze this systematically. First consider when it rains (no school) – we only look into one scenario since all other possibilities would yield him submitting assignments anyway. Thus first find P(Rain). We know P(No Teacher)=P(Substitute)+P(Not Substitute), which equals .5+(.5)*(.4)=.7; so probability rain=1-.7=.3. Similarly calculate P(Extended Homework|~Teacher). This yields (.4*2/3)/[(.4*.7)]=(2/.3)-or approximately ~67%. Even if the normal teacher comes in, there's a 40% chance she'll give everyone an extension. direct_answer.text:

This means we multiply them directly since these aren’t independent probabilities—if one occurs it affects the likelihood of another event happening as well. direct_answer.text: To find the probability that Neither the Regular Teacher Nor Substitute Teacher Will Show Up Tomorrow Morning We first consider the scenario where only the Regular Teacher may show up. Given this information, it means there exists another specific case apart from him showing up – namely someone else coming as well, which could include the substitution. Therefore, let T represent Event 'Regular Teacher Turns Up', S denote Event 'Substitution Occurrence'. Our interest lies exclusively in finding P(NotT AND NotS). Recall Probability Theory principle stating Complement Rule i.e.; \(P(\text{not } E)=1-P(E)\). Applying said Principle twice results into \(P(\text{neither } T \text {nor } S)=\left(1-P\left[T^{\prime }\right]\right)\times\left(1-P\left[S^{\prime}\right]\right)\) Consequentially applying Multiplication Rules indicates Independence Assumption Equality Validity Underpinning Condition Ascertain Scenario Context Relevant Statistical Model Employ Bayesian Approach Utilizing Posterior Distribution Compute Mean/Mode Estimate Result Let

direct_answer.text:
First let’s find out what happens when both events (a sub being present or not) happen together. This means we multiply them directly since these aren’t independent probabilities—if one occurs it affects the likelihood of another event happening as well. That makes this case tricky compared to something simple like flipping coins because coin tosses don’t depend on previous results! We need calculate all possible scenarios based off original probability values provided above; here goes our calculation listdown below::
(Substitute Teacher Not Present AND Substitute Doesn’t Give Extension): Probability=(Percentage Chance No Sub)(Chance Normal TA Gives EXT)=(50%)*(60%)%=30%. ::

To solve this problem, we need to consider all the different possibilities and their respective probabilities. We have four main events here:
Event S: having a substitute teacher (P(S)=50%)
Event E: receiving an extension despite the presence of a regular teacher (assuming no storm occurred, P(E)=40%). However, note that event N refers to 'no conditions', hence when calculating P(E|N) means 'receiving an extension under usual circumstances'.
